title: Exodus Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Exodus chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Exodus Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Exodus Chapter 21.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21:2, how long shall an Hebrew servant serve when bought?
options: Six years
Seven years
Five years
Ten years
questions.correctAnswer: Six years
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:2 states that if you buy an Hebrew servant, six years he shall serve.

questions.question: What shall happen to the Hebrew servant in the seventh year according to Exodus 21:2?
options: He shall go out free for nothing
He shall be sold again
He shall serve another master
He shall be freed with a payment
questions.correctAnswer: He shall go out free for nothing
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:2 says in the seventh year the servant shall go out free for nothing.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 21:6, if the servant chooses to stay, his ear is bored through with an aul.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:6 clearly states that if the servant loves his master and chooses to stay, the master shall bore his ear through with an aul.

questions.question: What must a master do if he takes another wife according to Exodus 21:10?
options: Not diminish the first wife's food, raiment, and duty of marriage
Send away the first wife
Give the first wife a payment
Ignore the first wife
questions.correctAnswer: Not diminish the first wife's food, raiment, and duty of marriage
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:10 instructs that if he takes another wife, he shall not diminish the first wife's food, raiment, and duty of marriage.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21:12, what is the punishment for he that smiteth a man so that he die?
options: He shall be surely put to death
He shall pay a fine
He shall flee to a city of refuge
He shall be imprisoned
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be surely put to death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:12 states that he that smiteth a man so that he die shall surely be put to death.

questions.question: If a man kills another without lying in wait, what does Exodus 21:13 say about his place of refuge?
options: A place shall be appointed where he shall flee
He shall be put to death immediately
He shall be exiled
He shall pay a ransom
questions.correctAnswer: A place shall be appointed where he shall flee
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:13 explains that if a man kills without premeditation, a place will be appointed where he shall flee.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Exodus 21:24: 'Eye for eye, _____ for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot.'
options: tooth
tooth
foot
wound
questions.correctAnswer: tooth
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:24 states: 'Eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot.'

questions.question: What is the punishment if a man steals a man and sells him according to Exodus 21:16?
options: He shall surely be put to death
He shall pay a fine
He shall be imprisoned
He shall be whipped
questions.correctAnswer: He shall surely be put to death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:16 states that he who steals a man and sells him shall surely be put to death.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 21:17 says cursing your father or mother will result in death.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:17 states that he who curseth his father or mother shall surely be put to death.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21:20, what shall happen if a man smites his servant and the servant dies under his hand?
options: He shall be surely punished
He shall be freed
He shall pay a fine
He shall be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be surely punished
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:20 states that if a man smites his servant and he dies, the man shall be surely punished.

questions.question: What payment is required if an ox gores a manservant or maidservant according to Exodus 21:32?
options: Thirty shekels of silver
Fifty shekels of silver
No payment required
One hundred shekels of silver
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty shekels of silver
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:32 says that if an ox gores a manservant or maidservant, the owner shall give thirty shekels of silver to their master.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21:22, what is the punishment if men hurt a woman with child and her fruit departs without further mischief?
options: He shall be punished and pay as the judges determine
He shall be put to death
He shall be freed
No punishment is given
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be punished and pay as the judges determine
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:22 specifies that if a woman with child is hurt and her fruit departs without further mischief, the man shall be punished and pay as the judges determine.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 21:21 states that a servant who dies after being smitten shall result in the master being punished.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:21 says if the servant continues a day or two after being smitten, the master shall not be punished.

questions.question: Who shall own the wife and children if the master gave a wife to his servant and she bore him children, according to Exodus 21:4?
options: The master
The servant
The children
The judges
questions.correctAnswer: The master
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:4 states that if the master gave his servant a wife and she bore children, the wife and children shall be the master's, and the servant shall go out alone.

questions.question: What must a master do if he does not provide food, raiment, and marriage duty to his wife according to Exodus 21:11?
options: The wife shall go out free without money
The wife shall remain with him
The wife shall be sold
The wife shall be punished
questions.correctAnswer: The wife shall go out free without money
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:11 states that if the master does not provide these three things, the wife shall go out free without money.

medium.title: Exodus Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Exodus Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with forgiveness after being wronged at work. Based on Exodus 21, what biblical principle about justice and mercy can you share?
options: Justice requires fair punishment but also restoration and healing
Revenge is the best way to honor God's law
Ignoring wrongdoing is the path to peace
Punishment should always be harsh and without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Justice requires fair punishment but also restoration and healing
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:18-19 teaches that if a man injures another but the injured recovers, the offender must compensate for lost time and ensure full healing, showing justice balanced with restoration. Verses 23-25 emphasize 'life for life' but also proportionate justice.

questions.question: How does Exodus 21 teach us about faithfulness and contentment in family life through the servant’s choice to remain with his master?
options: A servant may choose to stay with his master if he loves his family and master
A servant must always leave after six years regardless of feelings
Family ties are less important than legal contracts
Faithfulness to God means never serving others
questions.correctAnswer: A servant may choose to stay with his master if he loves his family and master
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:5-6 shows that a servant who loves his master and family can choose to remain serving permanently, reflecting faithfulness, love, and contentment in his relationship over legal freedom.

questions.question: A believer is facing injustice in their workplace. Based on Exodus 21, what principle about integrity and responsibility can encourage them?
options: Owners are responsible to care and compensate for damage caused by their property
It's acceptable to ignore damages caused by your possessions
Compensation is only required if damage is intentional
No responsibility is required for accidents
questions.correctAnswer: Owners are responsible to care and compensate for damage caused by their property
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:33-36 teaches that if a man digs a pit or owns an ox that causes harm, he must compensate the injured party, highlighting personal responsibility and integrity in stewardship.

questions.question: How does Exodus 21 instruct believers about honoring parents and the seriousness of disrespect?
options: Cursing or striking parents results in severe consequences
Disrespecting parents is a minor issue
Parents should tolerate any behavior from children
Only physical harm to parents matters
questions.correctAnswer: Cursing or striking parents results in severe consequences
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:15 and 21 emphasize that striking or cursing one's parents is punishable by death, underscoring the biblical command to honor and respect parents seriously.

questions.question: In the context of marriage, what biblical truth does Exodus 21 teach about a husband's responsibilities?
options: A husband must not lessen his wife's food, clothing, or marital rights when he takes another wife
A husband may neglect his first wife if he takes another
Women have no rights in marriage
A husband can freely mistreat his wife
questions.correctAnswer: A husband must not lessen his wife's food, clothing, or marital rights when he takes another wife
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:10-11 states that when a man takes another wife, he must continue providing for the first wife's needs and rights, reflecting fairness, love, and responsibility in marriage.

questions.question: A believer asks about the value of human life and justice. How does Exodus 21 frame the principle of proportional justice?
options: Life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth
Revenge beyond measure is justified
One should ignore offenses to avoid conflict
Punishment is unnecessary for serious offenses
questions.correctAnswer: Life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:23-25 teaches the principle of proportional justice, emphasizing fairness in punishment and valuing human life equally.

questions.question: How does Exodus 21 encourage believers to demonstrate humility and contentment in difficult circumstances such as servitude?
options: A servant serves for six years and then goes free, but may choose to remain out of love
Servants have no rights and must serve forever
Freedom is always immediate upon servitude
Servitude is shameful and to be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: A servant serves for six years and then goes free, but may choose to remain out of love
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:2-6 shows that Hebrew servants serve six years and go free in the seventh, but may voluntarily stay if they love their master and family, teaching humility and contentment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 21, if someone unintentionally kills another, they must be put to death without any place of refuge.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:13 provides that if a man kills unintentionally, God will appoint a place of refuge where the killer can flee to avoid revenge, showing mercy and protection for unintentional acts.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 21 mandates that if a servant is physically harmed by his master and dies immediately, the master must be punished.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:20 states that if a man strikes his servant and the servant dies under his hand, the master must be punished, reflecting God's justice and protection for vulnerable individuals.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Exodus 21, if a man sells his daughter as a maidservant, she shall not go out as the ______ do.
options: menservants
slaves
sons
servants
questions.correctAnswer: menservants
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:7 teaches that daughters sold as maidservants have different conditions than male servants, emphasizing protective provisions in marriage and service.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand God's teaching on stewardship and accountability. What does Exodus 21 teach about owners' responsibilities for their animals?
options: Owners must keep dangerous animals restrained and compensate for harm
Owners have no responsibility for animal-caused injuries
Animals are responsible for their actions
Owners should sell dangerous animals without concern
questions.correctAnswer: Owners must keep dangerous animals restrained and compensate for harm
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:28-30 and 36 explain that if an ox kills or harms, the owner is responsible and may be punished if negligent, emphasizing accountability in stewardship.

questions.question: How does Exodus 21 guide us in dealing with bodily harm and reconciliation among believers?
options: If injury is not fatal and healing occurs, the offender must compensate and ensure full recovery
Injuries must be avenged with equal harm regardless of recovery
Believers should ignore injuries to maintain peace
Only deadly injuries require compensation
questions.correctAnswer: If injury is not fatal and healing occurs, the offender must compensate and ensure full recovery
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:18-19 teaches that when injuries occur but the victim recovers, the offender must pay for lost time and ensure thorough healing, promoting reconciliation and responsibility.

questions.question: In the context of spiritual discipline, what does the law about a servant who chooses to stay with his master teach us about voluntary commitment?
options: Voluntary commitment to service can be a sign of love and faithfulness
Service must always be forced
Freedom is always preferable to service
Commitment has no spiritual value
questions.correctAnswer: Voluntary commitment to service can be a sign of love and faithfulness
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:5-6 shows a servant can choose to remain serving if he loves his master and family, illustrating the value of willing service and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Exodus 21 instruct believers about dealing with conflict and preserving peace within the community?
options: Proportional justice and compensation help maintain peace
Revenge without measure is encouraged
Conflicts should be ignored
Violence is the only way to resolve disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Proportional justice and compensation help maintain peace
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:23-25 and 18-19 emphasize 'eye for eye' justice balanced with compensation and healing, guiding believers to fair conflict resolution and community peace.

questions.question: A believer is learning about stewardship. What does Exodus 21 teach about making restitution for property damage?
options: If a man opens a pit and an animal falls in, he must make restitution
Damages can be ignored if accidental
Only intentional damage requires payment
Restitution is unnecessary for animals
questions.correctAnswer: If a man opens a pit and an animal falls in, he must make restitution
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:33-34 teaches that if a man digs a pit and fails to cover it, causing an animal to fall, he is responsible to compensate the owner, reflecting integrity and stewardship.

questions.question: How does Exodus 21 teach us about justice and mercy in cases of injury to a pregnant woman?
options: If a woman miscarries but no further harm occurs, the offender pays a fine determined by the husband and judges
No penalty is required if the woman miscarries
The offender must be put to death regardless
The woman is blamed for the miscarriage
questions.correctAnswer: If a woman miscarries but no further harm occurs, the offender pays a fine determined by the husband and judges
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:22 teaches that if men cause a pregnant woman to lose her child but no further harm follows, the offender must pay a penalty as determined by the husband and judges, balancing justice and mercy.

hard.title: Exodus Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Exodus Chapter 21.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21:2-6, what signifies a Hebrew servant's voluntary lifetime service to his master?
options: His master gives him a wife and children
He declares his love for his master, wife, and children and his refusal to go free
He is sold to a strange nation
He is brought before the judges and freed
questions.correctAnswer: He declares his love for his master, wife, and children and his refusal to go free
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:5-6 explains that if the servant plainly says he loves his master and family and will not go out free, he is brought to the judges and his ear is bored, signifying lifetime service.

questions.question: In the context of Exodus 21:7-11, how is the treatment of a maidservant different from that of a male servant?
options: A maidservant serves only three years
A maidservant does not go out free as male servants do
A maidservant may be sold to a foreign nation
A maidservant has no rights to food or clothing
questions.correctAnswer: A maidservant does not go out free as male servants do
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:7 states that a maidservant sold by a man shall not go out free as the menservants do, reflecting different social and legal statuses.

questions.question: What is the consequence described in Exodus 21:12 for one who strikes a man so that he dies?
options: He must pay a ransom
He shall be surely put to death
He must flee to a city of refuge
He must serve as a servant for life
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be surely put to death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:12 clearly states that the one who kills another by striking shall be put to death, establishing the principle of capital punishment for murder.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21:13, what provision is made for one who kills without premeditation?
options: He shall be put to death immediately
He must pay a fine to the victim's family
He shall flee to a city appointed for refuge
He shall be sold as a servant
questions.correctAnswer: He shall flee to a city appointed for refuge
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:13 describes that if a man kills unintentionally, God will appoint a place where he can flee to escape revenge, referring to the cities of refuge.

questions.question: Which parallelism is evident in the punishment prescribed in Exodus 21:23-25?
options: Lex Talionis (law of retaliation)
Covenantal blessings
Prophetic judgment
Priestly atonement rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Lex Talionis (law of retaliation)
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:23-25 presents the lex talionis principle, 'life for life, eye for eye,' a well-known ancient Near Eastern legal concept emphasizing proportional justice.

questions.question: How does the punishment for striking a servant differ from striking a free man, according to Exodus 21:20-21 and 26-27?
options: No punishment for servants, death for free men
Fines for servants, death for free men
Punishment only if the servant dies; freedom if eye or tooth is injured
Immediate death for both
questions.correctAnswer: Punishment only if the servant dies; freedom if eye or tooth is injured
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 indicate punishment if the servant dies, but if the injury is less severe like loss of eye or tooth, the servant is freed (verses 26-27), showing a nuanced approach to servant protection.

questions.question: In Exodus 21:15 and 17, what is the prescribed penalty for cursing or striking one's parents, and what does this reveal about ancient Israelite values?
options: Fines and restitution
Community service
Death penalty
Exile from the community
questions.correctAnswer: Death penalty
questions.explanation: Both verses prescribe death for striking or cursing parents, emphasizing the high value placed on honoring parents in Israelite society.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 21:22, if a pregnant woman is hurt in a fight and miscarries but there is no further harm, the offender must be punished according to the woman's husband's wishes and judges' decision.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:22 states that if a woman miscarries due to a fight but no further harm follows, punishment is determined by the husband and judges, reflecting a legal procedure balancing injury and intent.

questions.question: What is the significance of the ear being bored with an aul in Exodus 21:6 in the cultural and legal context of ancient Israel?
options: It marks the servant as property permanently
It is a sign of being freed
It indicates ownership transfer to another master
It symbolizes judicial acquittal
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the servant as property permanently
questions.explanation: The piercing of the ear as described in Exodus 21:6 symbolized the servant’s permanent servitude to his master, a physical and legal mark of lifetime bond.

questions.question: How does the law regarding oxen in Exodus 21:28-36 illustrate the principle of owner responsibility in ancient Near Eastern law?
options: Owner is always innocent regardless of the ox's behavior
Owner is liable if the ox was known to be dangerous and caused death
Owner must sell the ox immediately after an incident
Owner must free any injured servant
questions.correctAnswer: Owner is liable if the ox was known to be dangerous and caused death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:29-30 holds the owner responsible if the ox had a history of dangerous behavior and caused death, reflecting the principle of negligence liability.

questions.question: Exodus 21:10-11 requires a man to provide certain things if he takes another wife. What must he not diminish for the first wife?
options: Her inheritance
Her food, raiment, and duty of marriage
Her freedom to leave
Her status as a servant
questions.correctAnswer: Her food, raiment, and duty of marriage
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 state that if a man takes another wife, he must not lessen the first wife's food, clothing, or marital rights, preserving her dignity and provision.

questions.question: What literary structure is evident in the arrangement of laws in Exodus 21, particularly the progression from servitude laws to personal injury laws?
options: Chiasm with servitude laws framing the chapter and injury laws central
Linear chronological narrative
Poetic parallelism throughout
Random legal collection
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm with servitude laws framing the chapter and injury laws central
questions.explanation: Exodus 21 displays a chiastic structure where servant laws frame the chapter and personal injury laws form the central portion, highlighting the transition from social to civil justice.

questions.question: How does the lex talionis principle in Exodus 21:23-25 foreshadow New Testament teachings on justice and mercy?
options: It is abandoned entirely in the New Testament
It is upheld without modification in the New Testament
It is transformed by Jesus into teachings of forgiveness and mercy
It is only applicable to priests
questions.correctAnswer: It is transformed by Jesus into teachings of forgiveness and mercy
questions.explanation: Jesus refers to 'eye for eye' in Matthew 5:38-39, urging followers to turn the other cheek, showing the lex talionis principle is fulfilled and expanded into mercy and forgiveness.

questions.question: In Exodus 21:16, what crime is punishable by death, and how does this reflect ancient Israelite views on human dignity?
options: Stealing property
Stealing a man to sell him (kidnapping)
Murdering an ox
Cursing a neighbor
questions.correctAnswer: Stealing a man to sell him (kidnapping)
questions.explanation: Verse 16 condemns kidnapping and selling a person as capital offense, affirming the value and dignity of human life in Israelite law.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Exodus 21:34, if a man digs a pit and does not cover it, and an ox or an ass falls in, the owner of the pit must ______ and give money to the owner of the animal.
options: Fill the pit
Make it good
Set a watch
Report to the elders
questions.correctAnswer: Make it good
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:34 requires the owner of an uncovered pit to 'make it good' and compensate the animal’s owner, showing responsibility for property hazards.

theological.title: Exodus Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Exodus Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21, what duration of service is prescribed for a Hebrew servant before being set free?
options: Six years of service, free in the seventh
Seven years of service, free in the eighth
Five years of service, free in the sixth
Ten years of service, free in the eleventh
questions.correctAnswer: Six years of service, free in the seventh
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:2 commands that a Hebrew servant serve for six years and be free in the seventh. This highlights God's provision for restoration and freedom, similar to the sabbatical year principle in Leviticus 25:40, and reflects the principle of liberty and redemption also seen in Galatians 5:1 and the servant's release in Jeremiah 34:14.

questions.question: What happens if a Hebrew servant declares love for his master, wife, and children and chooses not to go out free?
options: His master shall bore his ear through, and he shall serve forever
He shall be forced to leave immediately
He shall be sold to another master
He shall be given a new wife
questions.correctAnswer: His master shall bore his ear through, and he shall serve forever
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:5-6 describes the voluntary lifelong servitude as a sign of devotion, symbolized by the piercing of the ear. This act signifies covenant faithfulness (cf. Leviticus 19:17-18 on loving one's neighbor), and points typologically to Christ’s enduring covenant with his people (Hebrews 13:5, John 15:15).

questions.question: What is the prescribed punishment for one who kills another person intentionally, according to Exodus 21?
options: He shall be put to death
He shall pay a fine
He shall serve as a servant
He shall flee to a city of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be put to death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:12 states that one who strikes a man so that he dies shall surely be put to death, affirming the sanctity of human life and God's justice (Genesis 9:6, Numbers 35:31, Matthew 5:21-22). This principle also underscores the seriousness of sin against others, echoing the divine judgment theme throughout Scripture.

questions.question: If a man kills another unintentionally, what provision does Exodus 21 make for him?
options: He may flee to a place of refuge
He must be put to death
He should pay a ransom
He should serve the victim's family
questions.correctAnswer: He may flee to a place of refuge
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:13 explains that if a man kills unintentionally, God appoints a place for him to flee, providing protection from vengeance. This demonstrates God's mercy alongside justice (Numbers 35:11-28, Joshua 20:1-9) and prefigures New Testament themes of grace and refuge in Christ (Hebrews 6:18).

questions.question: What law is given in Exodus 21 regarding striking a parent?
options: The one who strikes his father or mother shall be put to death
He shall be fined
He shall be forgiven after repentance
He shall serve a year as punishment
questions.correctAnswer: The one who strikes his father or mother shall be put to death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:15 pronounces death for striking one's parents, emphasizing the divine order of family and respect (Deuteronomy 27:16, Matthew 15:4). This reflects the holiness of God's covenant community and the importance of honoring authority as commanded in the Ten Commandments (Exodus 20:12).

questions.question: What is the penalty for stealing and selling a person as stated in Exodus 21?
options: The thief shall be put to death
The thief shall pay a fine
The thief shall serve as a servant
The thief shall be publicly shamed
questions.correctAnswer: The thief shall be put to death
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:16 declares that stealing a person and selling him is punishable by death, showing the gravity of human trafficking and the sacredness of human dignity (Deuteronomy 24:7, Jeremiah 34:16). This law reflects God's justice and the imago Dei principle that all humans bear God's image (Genesis 1:27).

questions.question: If two men fight and one strikes the other causing injury but not death, what restitution must the offender make?
options: Pay for lost time and ensure full healing
Be put to death
Serve the injured man for a year
Offer a burnt offering
questions.correctAnswer: Pay for lost time and ensure full healing
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:18-19 commands that if the injured recovers, the offender pays for lost time and ensures thorough healing, reflecting God's justice balanced with mercy (Leviticus 24:19-20, Luke 10:25-37). This principle underscores accountability and restoration in interpersonal relationships.

questions.question: What does Exodus 21 say about a master who kills his servant by striking him with a rod?
options: He shall be punished if the servant dies immediately
He shall be rewarded for discipline
He shall pay a fine but not be punished
He shall set the servant free
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be punished if the servant dies immediately
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:20 states that if a master strikes his servant and the servant dies immediately, the master shall be punished, affirming the value of servant's life and justice (Deuteronomy 24:14-15, Colossians 4:1). This law protects the vulnerable and enforces accountability for abuse.

questions.question: What is the law regarding injury to a pregnant woman who suffers a miscarriage due to a fight, according to Exodus 21?
options: The offender shall be fined if no further harm follows
The offender shall be put to death regardless
The woman shall be blamed
No punishment is required
questions.correctAnswer: The offender shall be fined if no further harm follows
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:22 prescribes a fine if a pregnant woman miscarries but no further harm occurs, emphasizing the value of unborn life and justice (Psalm 139:13-16, Luke 1:41-44). This law balances mercy and justice and foreshadows the sanctity of life themes fulfilled in the New Testament.

questions.question: What is the principle expressed by "eye for eye, tooth for tooth" in Exodus 21?
options: Proportional justice ensuring punishment fits the offense
An endorsement of revenge
A literal call for mutilation
A ceremonial law no longer applicable
questions.correctAnswer: Proportional justice ensuring punishment fits the offense
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:23-25 teaches lex talionis, the principle of proportional justice, limiting vengeance and promoting fairness (Leviticus 24:19-20, Matthew 5:38-39). Jesus later deepens this principle by calling for mercy and forgiveness (Matthew 5:38-48), showing God's holiness and love.

questions.question: What must a master do if he injures his servant's eye or tooth, according to Exodus 21?
options: Let the servant go free
Pay a fine but keep the servant
Punish the servant
Ignore the injury
questions.correctAnswer: Let the servant go free
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:26-27 mandates that if a master injures his servant's eye or tooth, the servant must be set free, reflecting God's concern for the servant's dignity and justice (Deuteronomy 15:12-18, Luke 4:18-19). This law anticipates the liberation found in the gospel of Christ.

questions.question: According to Exodus 21, what must be done if an ox kills a man or woman?
options: The ox must be stoned and its flesh not eaten
The ox must be sold to another owner
The ox must be set free
The owner must sacrifice a lamb
questions.correctAnswer: The ox must be stoned and its flesh not eaten
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:28 orders that a deadly ox be stoned and not eaten, expressing the seriousness of life-taking and ritual purity (Numbers 19:11-22, Deuteronomy 21:1-9). The owner's exemption unless negligent shows God’s just balance between responsibility and mercy (Proverbs 17:15).

questions.question: What is the penalty if an ox owner knew of the animal's dangerous behavior but failed to restrain it, resulting in death?
options: The owner shall be put to death along with the ox
The owner must pay a heavy fine
The owner loses the ox but lives
The owner must build a fence
questions.correctAnswer: The owner shall be put to death along with the ox
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:29 specifies that if the ox was known to be dangerous and the owner neglected to restrain it, resulting in death, both ox and owner shall be put to death, illustrating accountability and justice (Deuteronomy 22:8, Luke 12:48). This principle reflects God’s righteous judgment against negligence causing harm.

questions.question: If a man digs a pit and fails to cover it, causing an animal to fall in, who is responsible for the loss?
options: The owner of the pit must make restitution
The animal's owner is responsible
Both share the loss equally
The animal is considered lost property
questions.correctAnswer: The owner of the pit must make restitution
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:33-34 places responsibility on the pit owner to compensate for the animal, emphasizing personal accountability and justice (Proverbs 22:8, Luke 19:8). This law promotes stewardship and care for others’ property, consistent with biblical ethics (1 Corinthians 10:31).

questions.question: How are disputes involving oxen that injure others resolved according to Exodus 21?
options: Sale of the live ox and division of the money between owners
The ox is given to the injured party
The owner must kill the ox without compensation

questions.correctAnswer: Sale of the live ox and division of the money between owners
questions.explanation: Exodus 21:35 explains that when an ox kills another ox, the live ox is sold and proceeds divided, showing equitable resolution and preventing escalation of conflict (Leviticus 6:1-7, Matthew 18:15-17). This reflects God's concern for justice and reconciliation.
